awd_titl_txt: Creating Precision Agriculture and Crop Protection Career Pathways via Industry Partnerships
awd_abstract_narration:
This project aims to expand agricultural career training in a region with a continual shortage of skilled labor.  The program is designed to produce graduates with the skills and knowledge to keep up with rapidly-changing technological advances and requirements in modern agriculture. It has the potential to advance knowledge and understanding within the field of Agricultural Education by creating an industry-driven, hands-on model for developing an Agricultural Sciences degree and certificate program that includes guided pathways from high school to four-year institutions. As an Hispanic Serving Institution and an Hispanic-Serving Agricultural Colleges and University, the College will work closely with high school districts to create pathways for low-income, underrepresented students to develop their skills and increase their earnings, encouraging future generations of agricultural technicians to remain in the region and address the skilled labor shortage.

This project aims to create precision agriculture and crop protection career pathways for students in a rural, agricultural region. The project also aims to create a robust transfer degree in Agricultural Science and two certificate programs, develop high school to secondary education pathways, and establish field experiences and internships. Industry partnerships will drive curriculum development and students will be connected to regional agricultural businesses. The project projects that at least 75 students will be enrolled in the degree and certificate programs by the end of the project period, with an 80 percent persistence rate.  It also projects that more than 400 high school and college students annually will be engaged in field experiences, internships, and other industry and college outreach activities.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: ALLAN HANCOCK JOINT COMMUNITY COLLEGE DISTRICT

perf_inst.perf_inst_name: Allan Hancock Joint Community College District

por.por_cntn:
Project Title: Creating Precision Agriculture and Crop Protection Career Pathways via Industry Partnerships

Award Number: 1800889

Principal Investigator: Erin Krier

Allan Hancock College is a federally designated Hispanic Serving Institution, public community college located in Santa Maria, California. Santa Maria is the largest city in an expansive rural, agricultural region on the central coast. Agriculture is the county’s most significant economic driver, with diverse opportunities that contribute nearly $3 billion to the local economy through production of over 100 different crops in addition to the strong support services and livestock production sectors.

Prior to the award of this grant, the agricultural-related academic opportunities at Allan Hancock College were limited to the well-established Viticulture and Enology program. The college had developed this robust program, which includes a 4-acre on-campus vineyard and an on-campus bonded winery, to address the needs of the flourishing local wine industry. While impressive and well respected, this program lacked the breadth to attract and prepare students in the study of myriad other agricultural pathways, leaving a notable lack of higher education options for local students and significant workforce gaps for a variety of companies seeking to hire local talent.

The outcomes of this project can be summarized as follows:

Objective 1: to create a robust transfer degree in Agricultural Science leading to a four-year degree

  • Established an Associate in Agricultural Science degree
  • Established an Associate Degree for Transfer in Agricultural Plant Science
  • Established an Associate Degree for Transfer in Agricultural Business

Objective 2: to develop two certificate programs that further the education of current and prospective agricultural technicians in the region in precision agriculture and crop protection

  • Established a Certificate of Achievement in Agricultural Science
  • Established a Certificate of Achievement in Crop Protection
  • Established a Certificate of Achievement in Pest Control Adviser Preparation
  • Established a Certificate of Achievement in Precision Agriculture
  • Created new courses for inclusion in certificate and degree programs:
    • Introduction to Agriculture Studies and Careers
    • Agricultural Plant Pathology
    • Economic Entomology
    • Weed Science
    • Qualified Applicator Training
    • Introduction to Precision Agriculture
    • Agriculture Enterprise Project, Fall
    • Agriculture Enterprise Project, Spring
    • Agriculture Enterprise Project, Summer
  • Revitalized the on-campus student farm to provide contextualized learning opportunities through research, production, sales, marketing, and pest management of over 50 fruit trees, greenhouse, and vegetable garden

Objective 3: to formalize agricultural education pathways from high school to higher education, including developing high school concurrent education opportunities and articulation agreements

  • Approved more than 20 local high school agriculture program courses for articulation to Allan Hancock College
  • PI serves on all advisory committees for local high school FFA chapters
  • Established an annual FFA Field Day to draw hundreds of high school students from around the state of California to compete in Best Informed Greenhand, Nursery/Landscape, Soil & Land Evaluation, Vegetable Crop Judging, and Veterinary Science contests
  • Developed a formal academic plan in collaboration with the Santa Maria Joint Union High School District Mark Richardson Career Technical Education Center and Agricultural Farm
  • Established regular visits to high school FFA classes to share program information and agriculture career pathways information
  • PI attends local and regional California Agricultural Teachers’ Association meetings to engage with high school teachers and collaborate on program development
  • Established formal collaborative programs with universities to encourage transfer-readiness
  • Received approval for articulation of several agriculture courses to California universities
  • Created a program to connect Allan Hancock College agriculture students with Cal Poly State University’s Summer Undergraduate Research Program for students to do paid research work with university students and professors
  • Partnered with universities on various field, outreach, and research projects that included student participation

Objective 4: to establish agricultural science field work experiences for high school and college students in partnership with local industry

  • Established a robust Business and Industry Leadership Team (BILT) with representatives from every sector of the local agriculture industry, including small- and large-scale crop production, pest control advising, food safety, organic certification, ag banking, research and extension, advocacy organizations, County Agricultural Commissioner, ag technology and automation, soil health management, USDA, and laboratory diagnostics
  • Host BILT meetings twice each year, once during fall semester and once during spring semester
  • Collaborate with BILT members to determine appropriate course and program direction to adequately prepare students to meet agricultural workforce needs
  • Developed consistent pipelines for paid student internships with industry partners
  • Established networks of industry supporters, advisors, and presenters to engage with students on an individual level

The results of this project are far-reaching and forever engrained in the fabric of the community. This work has increased accessibility to higher education in agriculture for the diverse population of students seeking to prepare for or advance in careers in agriculture. This grant served as a springboard for the creation of boundless opportunities for students seeking technical training for living-wage employment and providing the academic preparation necessary for success in university transfer and completion.

 


Last Modified: 11/13/2023
Modified by: Erin Krier

Images (1 of )
  • The on-campus student farm provides contextualized learning opportunities via field research trials, crop production projects, pest management demonstrations, and implementation of emerging agricultural technologies.
    Allan Hancock College
    Copyrighted
    Erin Krier
    Students Working at Campus Farm
  • The diverse student population at Allan Hancock College now has access to various pathways of study designed to meet local industry needs, including crop protection, precision agriculture, plant science, agribusiness, and agricultural science.
    Allan Hancock College
    Copyrighted
    Erin Krier
    Agricultural Science Students at Farm
